facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 236 of 1966 in the Supreme Court's Criminal Appellate Jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 236 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal is by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 24, 1965 of the Punjab High Court, Circuit Bench at Delhi in Criminal Appeal No. 16-D of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 24, 1965 of the Punjab High Court, Circuit Bench at Delhi in Criminal Appeal No. 16-D of 1964.

facts.text: Respondent has been acquitted by the High Court (Dulat, J.).

anchor.surface_text: The respondent has been acquitted by the High Court  Dulat, J. . The relevant facts are as follows The respondent

facts.text: Basic facts in this appeal are not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: Sikri, C.J--The basic facts in this appeal, by special leave, are number in dispute and the only question

facts.text: Respondent was an Income-tax officer for about ten years from December, 1950 to September, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts are as follows The respondent was an Income-tax officer for about ten years from December, 1950 to September, 1960.

facts.text: While posted at Amritsar during 1954-55, respondent obtained petrol on credit from a petrol pump, bill Rs. 151, did not pay.

anchor.surface_text: While he was posted at Amritsar during the year 1954-55 he obtained on credit petrol from a petrol pump and the bill came to Rs. 151. It is stated that the respondent did number pay this bill.

facts.text: Respondent posted at Delhi from 1955 to 1958, obtained goods on credit from Ms Empire Stores worth Rs. 2,876.20, did not pay.

anchor.surface_text: Later, he was posted at Delhi from 1955 to 1958 and at Delhi he obtained goods on credit from M s Empire Stores and during the period of about three years he purchased goods worth Rs. 2,876.20.

facts.text: Respondent purchased goods on credit from Ms Sylco (cloth merchants and tailors), owed Rs. 1,853.10, did not pay.

anchor.surface_text: He also purchased goods on credit from M s Sylco, who are cloth merchants as well as tailors. To them he owed Rs. 1,8 53 10 and he also has number paid this bill.

facts.text: Respondent owed Rs. 71.75 to Ms Electronics Limited.

anchor.surface_text: He owed Rs. 71. 7 5 to M s Elec- tronics Limited.

facts.text: Respondent purchased a refrigerator from Ms Oriental Radio Corporation at a concession of Rs. 150, admitted his liability.

anchor.surface_text: He purchased a refrigerator from M s Oriental Radio Corporation at a companycession of Rs. 150 The respondent admitted his liability.

facts.text: Learned Special Judge found that respondent had means to pay during relevant period and deliberately did not pay.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Special Judge found that the respondent had means to pay during the relevant period and he did number deliberately pay.

facts.text: Special Judge inferred that respondent never intended to make the payment, relied on period of limitation to recover amounts having expired.

anchor.surface_text: From this he drew the inference that the respondent never intended to make the payment. He relied on the fact that the period of limitation to recover these amounts had expired.

facts.text: P.W. 13, Mukand Lal, partner of Ms Empire Stores, prosecution witness, stated firm allowed respondent credit sales as known customer, all customers got credit facilities.

anchor.surface_text: In this case P. W. 13, Mukand Lal, partner of M s. Empire Stores, who appeared as a prosecution witness, stated that the firm allowed the respondent credit sales in his capacity as a known customer and all their customers got credit facilities.

facts.text: Mukand Lal stated firm allowed customers fairly long terms of credit, usually avoided going to court for recovery, got payment from customers even if barred by time.

anchor.surface_text: He further said that the firm allowed customers fairly long terms of credit. They usually avoided going to companyrt for the recovery of their dues, and they got payment from their customers of dues whose recovery had become barred by time.

facts.text: Mukand Lal stated firm still expected amounts standing against respondent would be paid by him.

anchor.surface_text: He also added that the firm still expected that the amounts standing against the respondent would be paid by him.

facts.text: No evidence that respondent obtained credit only because he was an Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: It does number appear that there was any suggestion that the respondent obtained this credit only because he was an Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Firms give credit to officers not because they are officers but because they know they have fixed salaries from which bills could be realised.

anchor.surface_text: Firms give credit to officers number because they are officers but because they know that they are persons with fixed salaries from which the bills companyld be realised.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds no offence under Section 5(1)(b) of the Act committed.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the High Court was quite right in holding that numberoffence had been companymitted under Section 5  1   b  of the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds offence under Section 5(1)(d) not proved.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the High-Court was right in holding that offence under Section 5  1   d  had number been proved.

facts.text: Appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the,. result the appeal fails and-is dismissed.

issues.text: whether on the facts, as found, the respondent should be convicted under Section 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947

anchor.surface_text: the only question involved is whether on the facts, as found, the respondent should be companyvicted under Section  5   2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947  hereinafter referred

issues.text: whether obtaining goods on credit amounts to obtaining valuable things without consideration or for inadequate consideration under Section 5(1)(b) of the Prevention of Corruption Act

anchor.surface_text: clause  b  of sub-section  1  of Section 5 of the Prevention of- Corruption Act did number companytemplate the case of a purchase on credit accepted as a valid promise by the giver or the creditor. The High Court was accordingly unable to agree with the learned Special Judge that the obtaining of these goods was without companysideration within the meaning of Section  5   1   b  of the Act. The High Court next companysidered Clause  d  of Section 5  1  of the Act. these contracts were per se illegal and void under Section 23 of the Contract Act.

issues.text: whether the credit sales were illegal transactions under Section 5(1)(d) of the Prevention of Corruption Act

anchor.surface_text: Section  5   1   b  of the Act. The High Court next companysidered Clause  d  of Section 5  1  of the Act. The High Court differed from the learned Special Judge and held that the credit sales were number illegal transactions It was urged before the High Court that if the respondent never intended to pay for the goods he purchased from the various shops then the respondent obviously cheated, those shopkeepers. and since cheating- was certainly illegal, it must be held that the respondent obtained goods by illegal means and that would be an offence under Section 5 1   d  of the Act. The High Court, however, felt companyvinced that Clause  d  of Section 5 1 , although it did literally seem to companyer the transactions, was number designed or intended to companyer such cases.

issues.text: whether the respondent had obtained any pecuniary advantage under Section 5(1)(d) of the Prevention of Corruption Act

anchor.surface_text: Coming to Section 5  1   d , the question arises whether the respondent had obtained any pecuniary advantage. There is numberdoubt that the words pecuniary advantage are of wide amplitude but even so in the companytext of Section 5  1   d  obtaining goods on credit cannot be held to amount to obtaining pecuniary advantage.

arguments.claim: Respondent obtained valuable things without consideration or for inadequate consideration under Section 5(1)(b) as he had means to pay but deliberately did not pay, never intended to pay, and contracts were illegal and void under Section 23 of the Contract Act

anchor.surface_text: According to. the prosecution all this amounted to obtaining valuable things without companysideration or for companysideration which the respondent knew to, be inadequate. The learned Special Judge found that the respondent had means to pay during the relevant period and he did number deliberately pay. From this he drew the inference that the respondent never intended to make the payment. He relied on the fact that the period of limitation to recover these amounts had expired. According to the Special Judge these companytracts were per se illegal and void under Section 23 of the Contract Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agreed; no pecuniary advantage without agreement not to pay

arguments.claim: No offence under Section 5(1)(b); there was consideration in obtaining goods on credit unless proved there was agreement that trader would not demand payment and officer not pay

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the High Court was quite right in holding that numberoffence had been companymitted under Section 5  1   b  of the Act. It seems to us that there was companysideration for the obtaining of goods on credit and it cannot be said that an officer, if he obtains goods on credit, even if he does number intend to pay, is obtaining a valuable thing without companysideration. The case may be different if it is proved that there was an agreement with the trader that the trader would number demand the money and the officer would number pay, and the bill and the reminders sent would be merely a formality. There is numberevidence to sustain such an inference in this particular case.

arguments.claim: No offence under Section 5(1)(d); obtaining goods on credit does not amount to pecuniary advantage unless agreement that officer not expected to pay; supported by witness evidence of normal credit practices and expectation of payment

anchor.surface_text: Coming to Section 5  1   d , the question arises whether the respondent had obtained any pecuniary advantage. There is numberdoubt that the words pecuniary advantage are of wide amplitude but even so in the companytext of Section 5  1   d  obtaining goods on credit cannot be held to amount to obtaining pecuniary advantage. As we have said, if there is an agreement between the officer and the trader that the officer is number expected to pay for the goods then there is numberdoubt that this would amount to obtaining pecuniary advantage, but if there is numbersuch agreement and the officer does number pay it cannot be said that he has obtained any pecuniary advantage. He does number act in any manner different from a numberofficial who obtains things on credit and then refuses to pay. In this case P. W. 13, Mukand Lal, partner of M s. Empire Stores, who appeared as a prosecution witness, stated that the firm allowed the respondent credit sales in his capacity as a known customer and all their customers got credit facilities. He further said that the firm allowed customers fairly long terms of credit. They usually avoided going to companyrt for the recovery of their dues, and they got payment from their customers of dues whose recovery had become barred by time. He also added that the firm still expected that the amounts standing against the respondent would be paid by him. It does number appear that there was any suggestion that the respondent obtained this credit only because he was an Income-tax Officer.

arguments.claim: Firms give credit to officers not because they are officers but because fixed salaries from which bills could be realised; otherwise impossible for officers to obtain credit without risking charge under Section 5(1)(d)

anchor.surface_text: Firms give credit to officers number because they are officers but because they know that they are persons with fixed salaries from which the bills companyld be realised. If we were to hold otherwise it would be impossible for any officer to go to a shop and obtain credit for if he did number pay within a reasonable-time a charge. companyld be levied against him under Section 5  1   d  of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the High Court was quite right in holding that numberoffence had been companymitted under Section 5  1   b  of the Act. It seems to us that there was companysideration

holdings.reasoning_summary: There was consideration for goods obtained on credit via promise to pay; differs if sham agreement proved not to demand or pay, but no evidence here

holdings.text: there was consideration for the obtaining of goods on credit and it cannot be said that an officer, if he obtains goods on credit, even if he does not intend to pay, is obtaining a valuable thing without consideration

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that there was companysideration for the obtaining of goods on credit and it cannot be said that an officer, if he obtains goods on credit, even if he does number intend to pay, is obtaining a valuable thing without companysideration. The case may be different if it is proved that there was an agreement with the trader that the trader would number demand the money and the officer would number pay, and the bill and the reminders sent would be merely a formality. There is numberevidence to sustain such an inference in this particular case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Promise to pay constitutes consideration in credit transactions; requires proof of agreement not to pay for exception, absent here

holdings.text: in the context of Section 5(1)(d) obtaining goods on credit cannot be held to amount to obtaining pecuniary advantage

anchor.surface_text: Coming to Section 5  1   d , the question arises whether the respondent had obtained any pecuniary advantage. There is numberdoubt that the words pecuniary advantage are of wide amplitude but even so in the companytext of Section 5  1   d  obtaining goods on credit cannot be held to amount to obtaining pecuniary advantage.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pecuniary advantage requires agreement that officer not expected to pay; otherwise same as non-payment by any customer

holdings.text: the High-Court was right in holding that offence under Section 5(1)(d) had not been proved

anchor.surface_text: In our view the High-Court was right in holding that offence under Section 5  1   d  had number been proved.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No illegal means or abuse yielding pecuniary advantage; normal credit practices evidenced, expectation of payment, policy against broad interpretation crippling officers' credit access

holdings.text: Firms give credit to officers not because they are officers but because they know that they are persons with fixed salaries from which the bills could be realised. If we were to hold otherwise it would be impossible for any officer to go to a shop and obtain credit

anchor.surface_text: Firms give credit to officers number because they are officers but because they know that they are persons with fixed salaries from which the bills companyld be realised. If we were to hold otherwise it would be impossible for any officer to go to a shop and obtain credit for if he did number pay within a reasonable-time a charge. companyld be levied against him under Section 5  1   d  of the Act.
